segment.source: Shows how to manually convert a Windows desktop application (like Win32, WPF, and Windows Forms) to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.
segment.target: Shows how to manually convert a Windows desktop application (like Win32, WPF, and Windows Forms) to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.

segment.source: Manually convert a Windows desktop application to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app
segment.target: Manually convert a Windows desktop application to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app

segment.source: Manually convert your Windows desktop application to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app
segment.target: Manually convert your Windows desktop application to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app

segment.source: Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.
segment.target: Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.

segment.source: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.
segment.target: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.

segment.source: Using the Converter is convenient and automatic, and it's useful if there's any uncertainty about what your installer does.
segment.target: Using the Converter is convenient and automatic, and it's useful if there's any uncertainty about what your installer does.

segment.source: But if your app is installed by using xcopy, or if you're familiar with the changes that your app's installer makes to the system, you can opt to create an app package and manifest manually.
segment.target: But if your app is installed by using xcopy, or if you're familiar with the changes that your app's installer makes to the system, you can opt to create an app package and manifest manually.

segment.source: Here are the steps to create a Centennial package manually:
segment.target: Here are the steps to create a Centennial package manually:

segment.source: Create a manifest by hand.
segment.target: Create a manifest by hand.

segment.source: Your appxmanifest.xml file needs to have the following content (at the minimum).
segment.target: Your appxmanifest.xml file needs to have the following content (at the minimum).

segment.source: Change placeholders that are formatted like THIS to actual values for your application.
segment.target: Change placeholders that are formatted like THIS to actual values for your application.

segment.source: Run the MakeAppX tool
segment.target: Run the MakeAppX tool

segment.source: Use the App packager (MakeAppx.exe) to generate an AppX for your project.
segment.target: Use the App packager (MakeAppx.exe) to generate an AppX for your project.

segment.source: MakeAppx.exe is included with the Windows 10 SDK.
segment.target: MakeAppx.exe is included with the Windows 10 SDK.

segment.source: To run MakeAppx, first ensure you've created an manifest file as described above.
segment.target: To run MakeAppx, first ensure you've created an manifest file as described above.

segment.source: Next, create a mapping file.
segment.target: Next, create a mapping file.

segment.source: The file should start with [Files], then list each of your source files on disk followed by their destination path in the package.
segment.target: The file should start with [Files], then list each of your source files on disk followed by their destination path in the package.

segment.source: Here's an example:
segment.target: Here's an example:

segment.source: Finally, run the following command:
segment.target: Finally, run the following command:

segment.source: Sign your AppX package
segment.target: Sign your AppX package

segment.source: The Add-AppxPackage cmdlet requires that the application package (.appx) being deployed must be signed.
segment.target: The Add-AppxPackage cmdlet requires that the application package (.appx) being deployed must be signed.

segment.source: Use SignTool.exe, which ships in the Microsoft Windows 10 SDK, to sign the .appx package.
segment.target: Use SignTool.exe, which ships in the Microsoft Windows 10 SDK, to sign the .appx package.

segment.source: Example usage:
segment.target: Example usage:

segment.source: When you run MakeCert.exe and you're asked to enter a password, select none.
segment.target: When you run MakeCert.exe and you're asked to enter a password, select none.

segment.source: For more info on certificates and signing, see the following:
segment.target: For more info on certificates and signing, see the following:

segment.source: How to: Create Temporary Certificates for Use During Development
segment.target: How to: Create Temporary Certificates for Use During Development

segment.source: SignTool
segment.target: SignTool

segment.source: SignTool.exe (Sign Tool)
segment.target: SignTool.exe (Sign Tool)
